title: How to Store Rugs

steps.headline: Clean the rug.
Moth-proof the rug after cleaning.
steps.description: There are a couple of choices here: either moth-proof the rug professionally using a commercial treatment, or use your own moth-proof treatments that you'd use for any stored fabrics in the home. The value of the rug should be accounted for when deciding which method to prefer.

steps.headline: Take care of humidity.
steps.description:
Humidity can cause a rug to curl at the edges, especially when humidity levels are constantly changing. Try to keep the storage space as dry and cool as possible. Keeping the storage temperature as even as possible is also very important. If the rug has curled, try pinning it down to the floor with double-sided tape for a way (heavy-duty). If not, then try steaming it back into shape. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/be\/1187658--3A.jpg\/460px-1187658--3A.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/be\/1187658--3A.jpg\/760px-1187658--3A.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":507.3626373626374,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Roll the rug for storage.
steps.description: If you fold the rug, it will gain permanent crease lines that are very hard, if not impossible, to remove and the fibers will be weakened at all bend points. Tie into a roll gently using twine or similar item.

steps.headline: Consider wrapping the rug in plastic or canvas cloth to protect it from dust.
steps.description: Do not use plastic if temperature changes will impact the storage space, as this will cause condensation. A canvas cloth or sheet will do an excellent job of keeping off dust, cobwebs, and the like.

tyn: Twine or similar to tie rug into a roll
text:
Clean the rug. If any part of the rug is soiled, it needs to be cleaned. Whatever is left on a rug can attract vermin, insects, or simply cause deterioration on its own account. If you are not sure how to clean the rug, read its label or seek professional advice. Always vacuum a rug before storing; this will remove dander, flea eggs, dust mites, etc., prior to storage. Use an appropriate setting on the vacuum so as not to damage it. If it cannot be vacuumed, at least beat the rug outdoors and leave it to air in sunshine for a day before storing. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/1187658--1A.jpg/460px-1187658--1A.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/1187658--1A.jpg/760px-1187658--1A.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":507.3626373626374,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} See the Related articles for a range of cleaning help for different types of rugs. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/1187658--1B.jpg/460px-1187658--1B.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/1187658--1B.jpg/760px-1187658--1B.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":507.3626373626374,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Moth-proof the rug after cleaning. There are a couple of choices here: either moth-proof the rug professionally using a commercial treatment, or use your own moth-proof treatments that you'd use for any stored fabrics in the home. The value of the rug should be accounted for when deciding which method to prefer. Take care of humidity. Humidity can cause a rug to curl at the edges, especially when humidity levels are constantly changing. Try to keep the storage space as dry and cool as possible. Keeping the storage temperature as even as possible is also very important. If the rug has curled, try pinning it down to the floor with double-sided tape for a way (heavy-duty). If not, then try steaming it back into shape. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/1187658--3A.jpg/460px-1187658--3A.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/1187658--3A.jpg/760px-1187658--3A.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":507.3626373626374,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Roll the rug for storage. If you fold the rug, it will gain permanent crease lines that are very hard, if not impossible, to remove and the fibers will be weakened at all bend points. Tie into a roll gently using twine or similar item. Consider wrapping the rug in plastic or canvas cloth to protect it from dust. Do not use plastic if temperature changes will impact the storage space, as this will cause condensation. A canvas cloth or sheet will do an excellent job of keeping off dust, cobwebs, and the like.
sentences: Clean the rug.
If any part of the rug is soiled, it needs to be cleaned.
Whatever is left on a rug can attract vermin, insects, or simply cause deterioration on its own account.
If you are not sure how to clean the rug, read its label or seek professional advice.
Always vacuum a rug before storing; this will remove dander, flea eggs, dust mites, etc., prior to storage.
Use an appropriate setting on the vacuum so as not to damage it.
If it cannot be vacuumed, at least beat the rug outdoors and leave it to air in sunshine for a day before storing.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b8\/1187658--1A.jpg\/460px-1187658--1A.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b8\/1187658--1A.jpg\/760px-1187658--1A.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":507.3626373626374,"licensing":"

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2c\/1187658--1B.jpg\/460px-1187658--1B.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2c\/1187658--1B.jpg\/760px-1187658--1B.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":507.3626373626374,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Moth-proof the rug after cleaning.
There are a couple of choices here: either moth-proof the rug professionally using a commercial treatment, or use your own moth-proof treatments that you'd use for any stored fabrics in the home.
The value of the rug should be accounted for when deciding which method to prefer.
Take care of humidity.
Humidity can cause a rug to curl at the edges, especially when humidity levels are constantly changing.
Try to keep the storage space as dry and cool as possible.
Keeping the storage temperature as even as possible is also very important.
If the rug has curled, try pinning it down to the floor with double-sided tape for a way (heavy-duty).
If not, then try steaming it back into shape.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/be\/1187658--3A.jpg\/460px-1187658--3A.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/be\/1187658--3A.jpg\/760px-1187658--3A.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":507.3626373626374,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Roll the rug for storage.
If you fold the rug, it will gain permanent crease lines that are very hard, if not impossible, to remove and the fibers will be weakened at all bend points.
Tie into a roll gently using twine or similar item.
Consider wrapping the rug in plastic or canvas cloth to protect it from dust.
Do not use plastic if temperature changes will impact the storage space, as this will cause condensation.
A canvas cloth or sheet will do an excellent job of keeping off dust, cobwebs, and the like.
